                Questions about Blumenthal dominated the early parts of questioning. | Getty

                        Republicans hone in on her relationship with informal adviser.

            By 
Josh Gerstein

10/22/15 08:08 PM EDT
Republicans and Democrats who were sharply at odds during most of the House Benghazi hearing seemed to agree on one thing: Hillary Clinton's longtime friend and prolific emailer Sidney Blumenthal was key to unraveling the puzzle.
Queries about Blumenthal dominated the early hours of the House session, with the GOP asserting that Clinton relied on Blumenthal for advice and sent it to others at State while ignoring requests from Benghazi for added security.
Story Continued Below
"A man who was a friend of yours, who had never been to Libya, didn't know much about it, at least that was his testimony, didn't know much about it, every one of those reports that he sent on to you that had to do with situations on the ground in Libya, those made it to your desk," Rep. Mike Pompeo (R-Kansas) declared. "You asked for more of them. You read them. You corresponded with him. And yet the folks that worked for you didn't have the same courtesy."
GOP members said it was telling that Ambassador to Libya Chris Stevens--one of the four Americans killed in the Sept. 11, 2012 attack--did not have Clinton's email address while Blumenthal did.
"Ambassador Stevens didn't have your email, is that correct? Your personal email?" Pompeo asked. "Did he have your fax number?....Did he have your home address?"
However, Clinton's aides and allies saw the focus on Blumenthal as proof that the committee had come up with nothing of substance during its 17-month investigation.



            By 
Nick Gass

"After 17 months and $4.7 million spent, their whole argument is about Sid Blumenthal?" longtime Clinton adviser John Podesta tweeted. "Blumenthal was not in the government & had nothing to do with the events that led to deaths of 4 Americans...No better proof that the Committee is totally political & completely undermines Gowdy's argument that investigation is on the level."
"The Republicans don't seem to realize that every minute spent talking about Sid Blumenthal is a minute they are losing," tweeted Dan Pfeiffer, former White House communications director and senior adviser.
Of about 12,000 Clinton emails released publicly so far by the State Department, 488 were to or from Blumenthal or contained his email address. GOP lawmakers said they now have about 150 emails from Blumenthal about Libya and Benghazi. Many also related to relations with Europe and former British Prime Minister Tony Blair's potential candidacy for chief of the E.U. At least one has been deemed classified by State, including information Clinton sent to Blumenthal, who had no security clearance.
Democrats on the panel called the GOP's protracted interest in Blumenthal bizarre.
"I just don’t understand the preoccupation with Sidney Blumenthal," said Rep. Adam Schiff (D-Calif.) "You would think that for the time we've spent on him he was in Benghazi that night manning the barricades."
While the discussion of Blumenthal often seemed removed from the core issue of whether the U.S. government should have done more to head off or respond to the Benghazi attacks, it was one of the few areas where Republicans seemed to throw Clinton off-balance.
While trying to parry questions from Benghazi panel Chairman Trey Gowdy (R-S.C.), Clinton sometimes strained her own credibility in an apparent effort to downplay the importance of Blumenthal's role.
"Did the president -- the same White House that said you can't handle him, and can't hire him -- did he know that he was advising you?" Gowdy asked, noting that Blumenthal appeared to have emailed Clinton more often about Benghazi and Libya than anyone else.
"He was not advising me," Clinton replied. "I have no reason to have ever mentioned that or know that the president knew that."
And despite ample evidence on the public record for months that Clinton repeatedly asked Blumenthal to keep sending her updates on Libya and other matters, she repeated previous assertions that his advice was unsolicited.
"I did not ask him to send me the information that he sent me," Clinton said. 
"You wrote to him, 'Another keeper, thanks' and 'Please keep them coming....Greetings from Kabul and thanks for keeping this stuff coming,'" Gowdy shot back.
Clinton then shifted slightly, conceding that she urged Blumenthal to keep up the flow. "They started out unsolicited and, as I said, some were of interest," she said.
Gowdy noted the concession, but acknowledged it wasn't exactly earth-shattering
"I don't want to be hypertechnical, because it's not a huge point, but it is an important point. You didn't say they started off unsolicited. You said they were -- you said they were unsolicited," the chairman said.
While Clinton minimized the significance of what Blumenthal sent along, she did not dismiss it entirely, and she defended forwarding the information to aides who sometimes scrambled to respond to the unusual dispatches.
"Some of it I found interesting, some of it I do not. Some of it I forwarded, some of it I do not," Clinton said.
Clinton went out of her way to note that Stevens said one report Blumenthal relayed seemed plausible. Stevens "actually said it rang true and it was worth looking into," she said.
In many ways, Blumenthal seems an improbable figure to suddenly find himself at the center of Washington discourse. Hiss decision to became a senior adviser to President Bill Clinton in 1997 confirmed suspicion among many journalists that as Washington editor of the New Yorker, he was already toeing the White House line.

Photo gallery

            By 
Diana D’Abruzzo

During his White House stint, Blumenthal sometimes made news, but usually as a result of bizarre storylines. In 1999, journalist Christopher Hitchens delivered an affidavit to Congress recounting a lunchtime conversation in which Blumenthal repeatedly called Bill Clinton paramour Monica Lewinsky "a stalker" and charged that Clinton was a "victim" of Lewinsky's advances.
Blumenthal also filed a defamation suit against online news impresario Matt Drudge, accusing him of publishing a false account claiming Blumenthal physically abused his wife.
After leaving the Clinton White House,, Blumenthal worked for a time as the Washington bureau chief for Salon.com. He also spent time as a freelancer and wrote books. He joined Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign as a senior adviser in 2007.
Allegations relating to Blumenthal's role in that campaign are what kept him from joining the State Department in 2009. Obama aides were convinced that Blumenthal spread false personal and policy rumors about Obama during the battle between Clinton and Obama for the Democratic nomination. While Clinton had more authority to name State Department personnel than any other Obama Cabinet member, Blumenthal was blacklisted--effectively banished by the White House.
When Gowdy asked about Blumenthal's rejection, Clinton didn't dispute it, but said she couldn't remember or didn't know who at the White House put the kibosh on her regular correspondent.
In a tweet marveling at Blumenthal's prominent role in Thursday's Benghazi hearing, former Obama campaign strategist and White House adviser David Axelrod still seemed to remember the Obama team's grudge against Blumenthal.
"Ironic that career kibitzer and conspiratorialist Sidney Blumenthal should be elevated to epic heights in GOP Benghazi conspiracy theory," Axelrod wrote.
